text: hi everyone welcome to IGCSE study buddy
where you can revise biology topics from
the Cambridge IGCSE syllabus
if you are enjoying these videos so far
please don't forget to hit the like
button and subscribe to our Channel
in this video you are going to learn
part 4 of topic 14 coordination and
response
let's learn about homeostasis
our body needs a stable internal
environment that is necessary for proper
cell and organ function
not having an internal balance can lead
to health problems and even death
factors like body temperature and blood
glucose levels need to be controlled for
proper body function
homeostasis is the maintenance of a
constant internal environment
homeostatic control by negative feedback
is a process that maintains a stable
internal environment in the body by
reversing any changes that occur from
the set point
the set point is a desired or ideal
value or a narrow range of values for a
particular Factor
for example the set point for normal
human body temperature is approximately
37 degrees Celsius
when the factor deviates from the set
point a negative feedback loop is
activated to return it to the set point
so say the conditions in the body change
from the set point
the change is detected
corrective mechanisms are activated to
correct the deviation
the conditions are returned to the set
point
and the corrective mechanisms are
switched off until it is needed again
so if the level of a certain variable
increases beyond the set point the
control systems work to decrease it and
if the level decreases below the set
point the control systems work to
increase it
the control of blood glucose
concentration in the body is a good
example of a negative feedback mechanism
we just learned about it in the previous
video but let's go through it again
if the blood glucose level in the body
goes up or gets too high the pancreas
will detect this and release the hormone
insulin
this hormone travels to the liver and it
stimulates the liver to remove excess
glucose from the blood and convert it
into glycogen and then store it this
brings the glucose level back down
when our body uses up glucose our blood
glucose levels get too low
when this happens the pancreas secretes
a hormone called glucagon
glucagon travels to the liver and it
stimulates the liver to break down the
stored glycogen into glucose and release
it into the blood to bring the glucose
level back up
let's talk about type 1 diabetes
type 1 diabetes is a condition where the
body is unable to control blood glucose
levels due to the lack of insulin
production by the pancreas
as a result blood glucose levels are
usually too high in individuals with
type 1 diabetes
type 1 diabetes can be treated by
injecting insulin
the additional insulin prompts the liver
to convert glucose into glycogen causing
the blood glucose level to reduce
additionally people with type 1 diabetes
need to monitor their blood glucose
levels regularly
take extra care of their diet avoiding
foods that cause significant spikes in
blood glucose
and exercise regularly which can lower
blood glucose levels through increased
muscle respiration
now let's move on to the skin
you should be able to identify the parts
of the skin
these are hairs
these are hair erector muscles
these are the sweat glands
these are receptors
these are sensory neurons
these are blood vessels
and this is the fat tissue
the skin of mammals plays an important
role in maintaining a constant internal
body temperature
this is also part of a homeostatic
process
the human body maintains an optimal
temperature of around 37 degrees Celsius
for enzyme activity
if the temperature exceeds this optimal
range enzymes can denature and not work
properly
here's what happens when there is a
temperature change in the body
the change is detected by
thermoreceptors or temperature receptors
in the brain and skin
nervous impulses are sent to the brain
through Sensory neurons
the brain responds by sending nerve
impulses to effectors in the skin
and the skin will carry out the response
so the mechanisms that help mammals
maintain a constant internal body
temperature are insulation
sweating
shivering
and adjusting the blood vessels that is
vasodilation and vasoconstriction
first insulation when it is called fatty
tissue in the skin serves as an
insulating layer that helps to prevent
excessive heat loss from the body
through the skin
also when it is cold hair erector
muscles contract and skin hairs stand
upright to trap a layer of air between
them
air is an insulator so it helps reduce
heat loss
when it is hot
hair erector muscles relax and the skin
hairs lie flat allowing unrestricted air
circulation which increases heat loss to
the environment
this helps cool down the body
so in hot conditions there is no
insulation provided by the skin hairs
sweating and shivering are also ways in
which the internal body temperature is
controlled when we feel hot the sweat
glands secrete sweat the sweat
evaporates off the skin
and the heat is lost to the surroundings
cooling the body
when it is called the body Shivers the
muscle contractions of shivering can
generate heat energy through respiration
thereby warming the body
now let's learn about vasodilation and
vasoconstriction
when we feel hot arterioles supplying
skin surface capillaries widen
therefore the blood flow increases
resulting in more heat being lost by
radiation
this cools the body down
on the other hand when we feel cold the
arterioles supplying skin surface
capillaries narrow thereby slowing down
the blood flow reducing the amount of
heat lost from the body
this helps conserve the heat because it
makes it harder for the heat to escape
the body temperature can increase then
the maintenance of a constant internal
body temperature in mammals involves a
negative feedback mechanism
the following diagram summarizes the
process
when the body gets too hot the
thermoreceptors in the brain and skin
detect the change in temperature and
send nerve impulses to the brain
the brain then responds by initiating a
series of responses including increased
sweating
vasodilation or widening of blood
vessels and flattening of skin hairs
the body cools back down to the normal
temperature through evaporative cooling
and increased heat loss through the skin
when the body gets too cold the
thermoreceptors in the brain and skin
detect the change in temperature and
send nerve impulses to the brain
the brain then responds by initiating a
series of responses including shivering
vessel constriction or narrowing of
blood vessels and
erection of skin hairs
the body warms up and returns to its
normal temperature since these responses
help generate heat and conserve heat in
the body
let's move on to the final topic of this
chapter Tropic responses
plants can respond to changes in their
environment called stimuli in order to
survive
examples of the stimuli they respond to
are light
water
and gravity
they can grow towards a stimulus that is
a positive response
or away from a stimulus that is a
negative response
these growth movements or responses are
collectively called tropisms
gravitropism is a response in which
parts of a plant grow towards or away
from Gravity
shoots are negatively gravitropic as
they grow upwards Against Gravity
whereas roots are positively gravitropic
as they grow downwards towards gravity
phototropism is a response in which
parts of a plant grow towards or away
from the direction of a light source
plant shoots are positively phototropic
as they move towards light in order to
maximize light absorption for
photosynthesis
plant roots are negatively phototropic
as they move away from light in order to
Anchor the plant and absorb water and
minerals from the soil particles
let's learn the role of auxin in
controlling shoot growth
plants control their growth chemically
auxins are hormones that control plant
growth auxins control the direction of
their growth in response to stimuli
auxins are made in the short tip
auxins promote cell division and
elongation in Plants the more oxygen
there is the faster they will elongate
and grow
only the region behind the tip called
the merry stem can contribute to growth
when light shines all around the tip the
growth is even since auxin is evenly
distributed this is what normally
happens with plants growing outside
auxins diffuse through the plant from
the shoe tip
when the light shines mostly from one
side however the auxins are unequally
distributed in response to light and
gravity and collects on the Shaded side
making those cells grow and elongate
faster than the cells On the Sunny Side
this causes the shoe to bend towards the
light
this is called positive phototropism in
plant shoots
phototropism and gravitropism of a shoot
are examples of chemical control of
plant growth let's investigate and
describe phototropism in shoots
place two plants in separate boxes with
a single light source coming from
different directions
so in box a the light will be coming
through a slit from the side so the
light will shine on the cells on only
one side of the stem and in box B the
light will come through a slit from
directly above the plant
so in box B the plant will grow directly
upward this is because auxin the plant
hormone diffuses equally down both sides
of the stem causing cells on each side
to elongate by the same length
in box a the plant stem bends towards
the light on the left this is due to
auxin accumulating on the Shaded side
which is the right side in this case
causing those cells to elongate more
than the cells on the left side
resulting in the stem bending towards
the light
therefore it is clear that shoots are
positively phototropic and will grow
towards whichever direction light comes
from
finally let's investigate and describe
gravitropism in shoots and roots
add damp cotton wool to two Petri dishes
place a bean seedling in the Cotton Bowl
in each petri dish
in Petri dish a the radical or root will
be facing downwards and in Petri dish B
the root is placed horizontally
cover both Petri dishes with lids
attach both Petri dishes to a support so
that they are on their sides
Place both Petri dishes in a light proof
box and leave for two days
observe the growth of the seedlings
in Petri dish a the root has grown
downwards that is a positive gravitropic
response and the shoot has grown upwards
that is a negative gravitropic response
in Petri dish B also the radical has
grown downwards that is positive
gravitropic response and the shoot has
grown upwards that is a negative
gravitropic response even though it was
initially placed horizontally
therefore it is clear that roots are
positively gravitropic that is they grow
towards gravity and shoots are
negatively gravitropic that is they grow
away from Gravity
so that concludes chapter 14
coordination and response
hope this video helped you please share
your thoughts and suggestions in the
comment section thank you for watching
and please don't forget to subscribe to
IGCSE study buddy for more biology
revision videos bye bye
